title: A Prospective, 5-Week, Open-Label, Randomized, Multi-Center, Parallel-Group Study With a 20-Week, Open-Label Extension Evaluating the Tolerability and Safety of Switching From Donepezil to an Initial Dose of 5 cm2 Rivastigmine Patch Formulation in Patients With Probable Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This study was designed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of switching from donepezil to an initial dose of 5cm\^2 rivastigmine patch formulation in patients with probable Alzheimer's Disease (MMSE 10-24). The study included a 5-week, open-label, randomized period followed by a 20-week open-label extension period. Patients were randomized to either an immediate switch from donepezil to rivastigmine patch formulation or to a switch to rivastigmine patch formulation following a 7-day withdrawal period.

groups.title: Immediate Switch
groups.description: Patients randomized to the immediate switch group continued treatment with donepezil through the evening prior to Day 8 of the study. On Day 8, all patients began open-label treatment with 5 cm\^2 rivastigmine patch formulation. A new patch was applied daily for 4 weeks. Patients who completed the core phase had the option of entering the extension phase, in which they received open-label treatment with rivastigmine patch formulation for an additional 20 weeks. In the absence of any dose-limiting adverse events (AEs), the dose was increased to 10 cm\^2 patch, and it remained the same through Week 25. Patients who experienced dose-limiting AEs had their dose reduced to 5 cm\^2 patch and continued on their best tolerated dose for the remainder of the study.

groups.title: Delayed Switch
groups.description: Patients randomized to the delayed switch group were switched to 5 cm\^2 rivastigmine patch formulation on Day 8, following a 7-day withdrawal period from donepezil. A new patch was applied daily for 4 weeks. Patients who completed the core phase had the option of entering the extension phase, in which they received open-label treatment with rivastigmine patch formulation for an additional 20 weeks. In the absence of any dose-limiting adverse events (AEs), the dose was increased to 10 cm\^2 patch, and it remained the same through Week 25. Patients who experienced dose-limiting AEs had their dose reduced to 5 cm\^2 patch and continued on their best tolerated dose for the remainder of the study.

achievements.comment: 1 patient was discontinued from the study the same day as randomization \& excluded from all analyses
Participants were required to sign a separate informed consent prior to entering the extension phase

measures.title: Age, Continuous
measures.description: Demographic data is provided for the Intent-to-treat / Safety population.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants Who Discontinued From the Study Due to Any Reason During the Core Phase of the Study
outcomeMeasures.description: The primary objective of the study was to evaluate the safety and tolerability of 2 paradigms for switching from donepezil to rivastigmine patch in patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD). The primary variable to assess tolerability of switching was the number of participants who discontinued from the study due to any reason during the core phase.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Safety population consisted of all randomized patients who had at least 1 post-baseline safety assessment. Patients were analyzed according to the treatment received.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline through the end of the core phase of the study (Week 5)

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants Who Discontinued From the Study Due to Any Adverse Event (AE) During the Combined Core and Extension Phases of the Study
outcomeMeasures.description: A secondary assessment of the safety and tolerability of 2 paradigms for switching from donepezil to rivastigmine patch in patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD) was the number of participants who discontinued from the study due to an AE during the combined core and extension phases of the study.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Safety population consisted of all randomized patients who had at least 1 post-baseline safety assessment. Patients were analyzed according to the treatment received.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline through the end of study (25 weeks)

outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Change From Baseline in the Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC) Score at Week 5 and Week 25
outcomeMeasures.description: The CGIC is an assessment tool used by a skilled clinician to make a judgment of the severity or a change of a patient's condition. The clinician relies solely on information obtained from the patient at the Baseline visit as well as clinical information obtained throughout the study period. The clinician does not have access to any post-baseline cognitive testing data. The CGIC is rated on a seven-point scale, ranging from (1) "very much improved" to (4) "no change" to (7) "very much worse".
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all randomized patients who entered the switch period for at least 1 day and had at least 1 post-baseline assessment of tolerability/safety. This outcome used observed cases without imputation (OC).
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline, Week 5 (end of the core phase) and Week 25 (end of the extension phase)

groups.title: Immediate Switch
groups.description: Patients randomized to the immediate switch group continued treatment with donepezil through the evening prior to Day 8 of the study. On Day 8, all patients began open-label treatment with 5 cm\^2 rivastigmine patch formulation. A new patch was applied daily for 4 weeks. outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Change From Baseline in Mini Mental State Exam (MMSE) Score at Week 25 and at the End of Study
outcomeMeasures.description: The MMSE is a brief, practical screening test for cognitive dysfunction. The test consists of five sections (orientation, registration, attention-calculation, recall, and language); the total score can range from 0 to 30, with a higher score indicating better function. A positive change score indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all randomized patients who entered the switch period for at least 1 day and had at least 1 post-baseline assessment of tolerability/safety. This outcome used observed cases without imputation (OC).
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline and Week 25 (end of the extension phase) and at the end of study

outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Change From Baseline in Neuropsychiatric Inventory - 10 Item (NPI-10) Score at Week 25 and at the End of Study.
outcomeMeasures.description: The NPI-10 assesses a wide range of behavior problems encountered in dementia patients. The 10 behavioral domains comprising the NPI-10 are evaluated through an interview of the caregiver by a mental health professional. The scale includes both frequency and severity ratings of each domain as well as a composite domain score (frequency x severity). The sum of the composite scores for the 10 domains yields the NPI total score, which ranges from 0 to 120, the lower the score the less severe the symptoms. A negative change score from baseline indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all randomized patients who entered the switch period for at least 1 day and had at least 1 post-baseline assessment of tolerability/safety. This outcome used observed cases without imputation (OC).
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline, Week 25 (end of the extension phase) and at End of Study

outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Change From Baseline in the Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study-Activities of Daily Living (ADCS-ADL) Total Score at Week 25 and at the End of Study
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADCS-ADL scale is composed of 23 items to assess the basic and instrumental activities of daily living such as those necessary for personal care, communicating and interacting with other people, maintaining a household, conducting hobbies and interests, making judgments and decisions. Responses for each item are obtained through a caregiver interview. The total score is the sum of all items and sub-questions. The range for the total ADCS-ADL score is 0 to 78; a higher score indicates a more self-sufficient individual. A positive change from baseline indicates improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population included all randomized patients who entered the switch period for at least 1 day and had at least 1 post-baseline assessment of tolerability/safety. This outcome used observed cases without imputation (OC).
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline, Week 25 (end of the extension phase) and at the end of Study

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certainAgreement.otherDetails: The terms and conditions of Novartis' agreements with its investigators may vary. However, Novartis does not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Any publications from a single-site are postponed until the publication of the pooled data (i.e., data from all sites) in the clinical trial.

drug: rivastigmine transdermal patch (Exelon) — 5 cm^2 initial patch (transdermal rivastigmine, cholinesterase inhibitor)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests switching from donepezil to a rivastigmine transdermal patch (5 cm^2). Both donepezil and rivastigmine are cholinesterase inhibitors used for symptomatic treatment of cognition in Alzheimer’s disease, i.e., they enhance cholinergic neurotransmission to improve cognitive symptoms rather than targeting underlying disease pathology. citeturn1search4turn0search7

Act: Key extracted details — intervention is rivastigmine transdermal patch (5 cm^2 patch corresponds to the 4.6 mg/24 h initial Exelon patch formulation) and the study population is probable AD (MMSE 10–24); patients were switched from donepezil (an AChE inhibitor) to rivastigmine patch. These products are indicated for symptomatic treatment of mild–moderate AD. citeturn1search4turn1search0turn1search1

Reflect: Classification check — this is a symptomatic cholinergic (cognitive-enhancing) therapy trial (switch/tolerability study of two cholinesterase inhibitors), not a disease-modifying biologic or small molecule aimed at AD pathology, nor a trial whose primary aim is neuropsychiatric symptom control or a diagnostic procedure. Therefore the correct category is 'cognitive enhancer'. No major ambiguity in the description. citeturn1search1turn0search7
explanation_agent: Reason: The study switches patients from donepezil to a rivastigmine transdermal patch. Both agents are cholinesterase inhibitors that increase synaptic acetylcholine to produce symptomatic cognitive enhancement rather than targeting core AD pathology; this mechanism is best captured by the CADRO category for therapies acting on neurotransmitter systems. citeturn0search5turn0search8

Act: Key extracted details — intervention is rivastigmine transdermal patch (Exelon) initial 5 cm2 patch = 4.6 mg/24 h; prior therapy donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. The trial is a tolerability/switch study of two cholinergic (cognitive-enhancing) drugs indicated for symptomatic treatment of mild–moderate AD. Based on these facts the appropriate CADRO assignment is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search7turn0search8turn0search9

Reflect: The classification was checked against CADRO definitions — this is not a disease-modifying anti-amyloid, anti-tau, anti-inflammatory, or other pathway-directed therapy but a symptomatic cholinergic approach increasing acetylcholine availability; therefore D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is the best fit. No evidence in the description indicates multiple biological targets or a non-therapeutic diagnostic focus, so 'R) Multi-target' or 'T) Other' are not appropriate. citeturn0search5turn0search7
- Exelon (rivastigmine) patch dosing, patch size and indications (initial 5 cm2 = 4.6 mg/24 h; indicated for mild–moderate AD). citeturn0search7turn0search0
- Rivastigmine mechanism: reversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase (increases acetylcholine). citeturn0search5turn0search4
- Donepezil mechanism: reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (symptomatic cholinergic therapy). citeturn0search8
